headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the AES First Quarter 2016 Financial Review Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Ahmed Pasha, Vice President of Investor Relati
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the AES First Quarter 2016 Financial Review Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Ahmed Pasha, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dan. Good morning, and welcome to our first quarter financial review call. Our press release presentation and related financial information are available on our website at AES.com. Today, we will be making forward-looking statements during the
componenttext:
Thank you, Dan. Good morning, and welcome to our first quarter financial review call. Our press release presentation and related financial information are available on our website at AES.com. Today, we will be making forward-looking statements during the call. There are many factors that may cause future results to differ materially from these statements. Please refer to our SEC filings for a discussion of these factors.
Joining me this morning are Andres Gluski, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Thomas O'Flynn, our Chief Financial Officer; and other senior members of our management team.
With that, I will now turn to the call over to Andres. Andres?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ahmed. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our first quarter financial review call. Today, I will discuss our first quarter results and provide updates on our progress on our strategic objectives, macro conditions in our markets a
componenttext:
Thank you, Ahmed. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our first quarter financial review call. Today, I will discuss our first quarter results and provide updates on our progress on our strategic objectives, macro conditions in our markets and our construction and development program. 
Since our last call in late February, we have achieved a number of key objectives for 2016. We received payment of all outstanding receivables in Bulgaria. We are on track to achieve our 3-year $150 million cost reduction and revenue enhancement goals. We saw improvements in our credit ratings and outlook from the rating agencies. Our $7.5 billion construction program is advancing on schedule and will be the major contributor to our cash and earnings growth over the next 3 years. 
We continue to leverage our existing business platforms by advancing projects with long-term contracts denominated in U.S. dollars. During the first quarter, we achieved significant milestones on 3 new projects, which will contribute to our growth after 2018. I will discuss these achievements in more detail in a moment. But first, I'd like to summarize our financial results on Slide 4. 
In the first quarter, we generated proportional free cash flow of $253 million in line with last year. The recent collection of $350 million in Bulgaria will be reflected in our second quarter cash flow. Our first quarter adjusted EPS was $0.13, which is considerably lower than the $0.25 we earned last year. Our first quarter operating performance was impacted by adverse movements in FX, lower power prices in the U.S. and the expiration of the power purchase agreement at Tietê in Brazil. 
Our earnings performance was also driven by a tax rate of 50% for the first quarter, which is really a timing issue. We continue to expect a 31% to 33% tax rate for the full year. 
In terms of our outlook for the full year, we are reaffirming our guidance on all financial metrics. Nonetheless, we expect our first half adjusted EPS to be relatively weak due to the continuing impact from the factors I just mentioned and schedule major maintenance in the second quarter. Now I'll turn to our strategic accomplishments since our last call. 
As you can see on Slide 5, we have successfully resolved the outstanding receivables issue at Maritza in Bulgaria. Maritza's sole customer, the National Electricity Company or NEK, have fallen significantly behind on its payments. In April, we received full payment of the outstanding receivables of $350 million. This is a direct result of the steps taken by the Government of Bulgaria to strengthen the financial position of NEK and the long-term sustainability of the energy sector. By meeting all of its contractual obligations, Bulgaria is sending a very positive signal to all foreign investors. Currently, Maritza's providing clinically needed power to the Bulgarian electric grid, and we have been collecting in a timely manner since December 2015. Turning now to Slide 6 and our cost savings and revenue enhancement initiative. 
Our goal is to achieve a run rate of $150 million per year in bottom line improvements. We are on track to achieve our $50 million goal for 2016 and the additional $100 million through 2018. These bottom line benefits are largely driven by global procurement efforts, moving back-office functions the lower-cost service centers in Argentina and Bulgaria, and continued improvement in the performance of our plans. Now turning to Slide 7. 
I'll discuss macro conditions in our markets. First, the impact from hydrology in Latin America should be negligible this year. While cumulative rainfall remains below-average in Panama, it is generally improved in the rest of Latin America. Regarding Panama, spot prices have fallen significantly as a result of the barge base powerplant we commissioned there last year, which reduced the effects of low rainfall on our contracted Hydro plants. 
Second, economic conditions in our markets are generally in line with prior expectations, except for Brazil, which is experiencing a deepening recession. At our distribution businesses in Brazil, we are now seeing a second consecutive year of 5% decline in demand. While in the U.S, demand is essentially flat, in most of our other markets, we'll continue to see energy demand growth in the range of 4% to 10%. Moving on to Slide 8. 
We are focusing our investment efforts on platform expansion projects with long-term contracts and U.S. dollar denominated revenues. We see a significant opportunity to take a leading role in the distribution and storage of LNG in Central America and the Caribbean. Turning to Slide 9. 
Let us review our major new projects. During the quarter, we started construction on the 335-megawatt Masinloc expansion to take advantage of robust growth in the Philippines and our existing infrastructure. The new unit, Masinloc 2, will be one of the most competitive thermal plants in the country, employing highly efficient and flexible supercritical technology. The $740 million project will be funded by a combination of non-recourse financing, partner equity and cash generated at the Masinloc 1 facility. Moving on to slide 10. 
I am pleased to report that we have achieved a number of milestones on our Colon project in Panama. This project encompasses both a 380-megawatt combined cycle plant, or CCGT, and an adjacent LNG regasification terminal and storage facility. The CCGT is contracted under 10-year U.S. dollar denominated PPA. The LNG facility will have 180,000 cubic meter tank, which is sufficient to handle 80 terra BTU annually. 
Our CCGT will use about 1/4 of a's tanks capacity, leaving substantial unused capacity to meet the needs of additional power plants or downstream customers. The Colon project seeks to replicate the success of our LNG facilities in the Dominican Republic, which provides gas to our adjacent powerplant, another power plant via pipeline and to numerous downstream customers in the transportation and industrial sectors. The Colon Project is strategically located near the entrance of the Panama Canal and will be able offer bunkling to the maritime industry as it starts use natural gases of fuel. There are many commercial synergies between the LNG terminals in the Dominican Republic and Panama. And with both facilities in service, we will become the largest provider of LNG regasification and storage services in Central America and the Caribbean. 
All of the Colon Project's permits are in place and have selected the EPC contractor. Project financing for approximately 60% of the project cost is well underway. AES' equity is expected to be around $200 million, which we will fund over the construction period. The project is expected to close in the second quarter of 2016 with completion of the powerplant in 2018 and the LNG facility in 2019. 
As we can see on Slide 11, the repowering of Southland in California is another example of a large project that will contribute to our growth beyond 2018. As a reminder, we were awarded a 20-year PPA by Southern California Edison for 1,384-megawatt of capacity, which includes 100 megawatts of energy storage and 1,284 megawatts of combined cycle gas capacity. Since our last call, we have signed turbine supply agreements and EPC contracts to build the CCGT. We are making good progress on the remaining regulatory approvals and expect to break ground in 2017 with completion in 2020. We anticipate funding the $2 billion total project cost with a combination of non-recourse debt and $500 million in equity from AES and a possible financial partner. Turning to Slide 12. 
We remain optimistic on the future battery base energy storage and our leadership position in this market. We currently have 116 megawatts of energy storage projects in operation across 4 countries and expect to install another 50 megawatts this year. Additionally, we have another 228 megawatts in advanced stage development, including the 100 megawatts under contract in California. By 2017, we expect to be operating in 7 countries, adding India, the Philippines and the Dominican Republic to the 4 countries where we already operate, the U.S, the U.K, the Netherlands and Chile. 
We see growth in our energy storage business through 2 paths. AES' own projects, such as the previously discussed 100 megawatts with the PPA with Southern California Edison and sales of our Advancion energy storage solution by AES in our channel partners. These sales were target utilities and other large energy storage customers. 
First, regarding long-term contracts. We see significant potential in many of our markets, including the U.S, the U.K, the Philippines and Mexico. We continue to work with local regulators to facilitate the development of market structures that enable new investments in battery base energy storage. 
Second, over the past 8 years, we have learned a tremendous amount about how to integrate the various components to create a proprietary battery based energy storage solution, which we have named Advancion. Tp promote Advancion sales in many more markets, we have executed general partner agreement with Mitsubishi for sales in Asia and with Eaton for sales in Europe, the Middle East and Africa. We are in discussions with other potential partners to sell Advancion in additional markets. 
Although battery based energy storage is still early on in its product cycle, we believe that Advancion presents an interesting opportunity for upside in our cash and earnings forecast. Turning now to our projects under construction on Slide 13. 
Our ongoing construction program is the most significant driver of our growth over the next few years. We expect to commission 6 gigawatts of new capacity from projects currently under construction through the first half of 2019. As a reminder, total capital expenditure for these projects is $7.5 billion. However, by using financial partners, AES' equity commitment is reduced to $1.3 billion. AES' equity commitment all but $160 million has already been funded. 
As you can see on Slide 13, roughly 74% of our investments are in the Americas, and of this, a majority is in the U.S. and Chile. We expect an average return on equity from these projects of approximately 15%. About 3 gigawatts representing half of the capacity currently under construction are 90% complete and are on track to come online, on time and on budget this year. 
In 2017, we plan to commission an additional 670 megawatts of capacity in the U.S. and 112 megawatts in the Dominican Republic. We have completed about 70% of the work on these 2 projects, and we also expect them to come online, on time and on budget. 
The remaining 3 major projects now under construction, Masinloc 2, PBGC 2 and Alto Maipo all projected to come online in late 2018 and early 2019. This construction program will drive visible and attractive growth in both free cash flow and earnings. 
As you can see on Slide 14, we expect at least 10% annual growth in proportional free cash flow through 2018, which will support our 10% annual growth in dividends, continued deleveraging of the parent and subsidiaries, and investments in attractive platform expansions. Turning now to Slide 15. 
We also see robust growth in earnings through 2018. From 2016 to 2018, we expect an attractive growth rate of 12% to 16% in our adjusted EPS. Approximately 5% of this annual growth rate is driven by cost reductions and revenue enhancements. Another 8% to 10% of expected growth is driven by the 2.4 gigawatts of construction projects coming online in 2017 and 2018. 
Based on our strong market position and attractive high-growth markets, we're optimistic about our ability to drive growth beyond 2018. The 3 projects I just discussed, Masinloc 2, Colon and Southland will come fully online after 2018. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Tom to discuss our first quarter results, capital allocations and full year guidance in more detail.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andres. Good morning, everyone. Today, I will review our first quarter results, including adjusted EPS, proportional free cash flow and adjusted pretax contribution, or PTC, by strategic business units or SBU. And I'll cover our 2016 capital alloc
componenttext:
Thanks, Andres. Good morning, everyone. Today, I will review our first quarter results, including adjusted EPS, proportional free cash flow and adjusted pretax contribution, or PTC, by strategic business units or SBU. And I'll cover our 2016 capital allocation, as well as our 2016 guidance. Turning to Slide 17. 
First quarter adjusted EPS of $0.13 was $0.12 lower than 2015. Much of this decline was driven by factors incorporated into our full year guidance with certain exceptions, primarily the decline in power markets in the U.S., as well as lower demand in Brazil. Specifically, our results reflect the $0.04 impact from a significantly higher quarterly tax rate of 50% in 2016 versus 33% in '15. This was mostly driven by the timing of certain tax expenses, the largest of which was of the enactment of income tax reforms in Chile. 
We do expect the rate to recover during the year to a full year tax rate of 31% to 33%. Next, the $0.04 impact from the valuation of foreign currencies, as expected, primarily Latin America and Europe. And also, $0.05 lower contributions from our SBUs mainly due to anticipated drivers, such as the expiration of Tietê's PPA with Eletropaulo. 
In addition to the drivers included in our expectations, we also saw some softness in power markets and mild weather in the U.S. That being said, we've seen some recovery in prices in the last month, which will contribute to our stronger second half of the or helps give us comfort in our full year outlook. Now to Slide 18. 
Our overall results were primarily driven by lower margins in our Brazil, Europe and U.S. SBUs due to the factors I just mentioned. We generated $253 million in proportional free cash flow, a modest decrease of $12 million from last year, reflecting lower margins mostly offset by higher collections at our Brazil utilities and lower working capital requirements in Vietnam. 
We also warrant $172 million in adjusted PTC during the quarter, a decrease of $80 million. Now I'll cover our SBUs in more detail over the next 6 slides beginning on Slide 19. 
In the U.S., our results reflect lower margins at DPL due to lower wholesale prices and lower contributions from regulated customers, lower contributions from IPL due to mild weather and a partial sell down and the sale of our Media Mountain Wind project. Proportional free cash flow also reflects unfavorable working capital changes at IPL. 
In Andes, our results reflect the 40% devaluation of the Argentine peso, 24% deval of the Columbia peso and lower volumes at Chivor in Colombia. Proportional free cash flow was also impacted by higher tax payments in Chile. PTC also reflects lower equity and earnings at Guacolda in Chile. 
In Brazil, our results reflect lower margins to the expiration of Tietê's PPA with Electropaulo in 2015, lower demand at Sul and Eletropaulo and the 26% evaluation of the Brazilian real. Proportional free cash flow also reflects higher collections in Sul and Eletropaulo, as well as the favorable timing of energy purchases at Tietê. 
Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean, our results reflect modestly lower margins. Proportional free cash flow largely reflects higher-than-normal collections in the Dominican Republic in 2015. 
In Europe, our results reflect lower margins due to the 48% devaluation of the physics and tenge and lower dark spread that occurred in the UK. Proportional free cash flow also effects the timing the timing of payments to the fuel supplier in Bulgaria and the unfavorable timing of working capital and tax payments in the U.K. 
Finally, in Asia, our results benefited from higher margins and lower buildup of working capital as a result of the start of operations at Mong Duong in Vietnam in April of 2015. Turning to Slide 25. I'll now provide an update in all regulatory filing at DPL in Ohio. 
As you may recall, in February, DPL filed into electric security plan. Since that time, there've been challenges to regulation in Ohio. This of the potential for similar arguments to impact the structure of other utilities proposals pending before the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio. Consequently, when we filed our plan, we included an alternative to proposal that provide an option for the PUCO to approve a nonbypassable charge structured in the same way as one approved in our existing ESP. 
We believe that this alternative falls under the PUCO's severity and also achieve the policy goals set up by the commission. We continue to believe this alternative provides a viable path forward for DPL and Ohio, and the commission is seeking for a reasonable resolution for the matter before the end of this year. Turning now to our 2016 parent capital allocation on Slide 26. 
Sources on the left-hand side continue to reflect $1.1 billion of total available discretionary cash, which includes $575 million in parent free cash flow and announced asset sales. We remain confident in our 2016 parent free cash flow range of $525 million to $625 million, which are the foundation of our discretionary cash available for dividend growth and value creation. Turning to the uses on the right-hand side of the slide, consistent with our capital allocation plan that we've shown during our last call, with 10% growth in our dividend and share repurchases year-to-date, we're returning at least 1/3 of this cash to shareholders. Going forward, we see our dividend as the primary means to distribute cash to shareholders. 
Stock repurchases should be less material as in proceeds with additional asset sales and partnerships. Regarding debt reduction, we're making good progress on our $200 million target for the year on our longer-term goal of parent credit improvement. In fact, year-to-date, we've prepaid $125 million of parent debt. Taking advantage of weak market conditions early in the quarter, we were able to buy this debt at a 7% discount. 
We're also seeing positive momentum on the ratings front. In March, Moody's changed our parent credit outlook from stable to positive. And in April, S&P upgraded our rating from BB- minus to BB. These actions reflect our continued efforts to derisk our portfolio and improve our credit metrics. 
We think the continuing to strengthen our credit will help us get better recognition and valuation for our growing cash flow and dividend. This positive quite a trend, along with an overall market improvement, has allowed us to continue to be opportunistic regarding refinancing and extending maturities. To that end, last 3, we extended an $800 million parent revolver maturity from 2018 to 2021. Also last week, on the non-recourse side, our business in the Dominican Republic was able to replace a short-term financing with a new $370 million, 10-year bond at more favorable terms. 
We've also earmarked $330 million for investments in our subsidiaries, but 13, of which is through our Colon project in Panama and in Southpoint in California coming online after 2018. 
Finally, after considering these investments in our subs, our current dividend and debt prepayment were left with roughly $150 million of discretionary cash, which we'll invest consistent with our capital allocation framework. As the year's past, much of this cash is weighted towards the latter part of the year. Now to slide 27. 
We are reaffirming our guidance in 2017, '18 expectations for all metrics based on foreign currency and commodity forward curves as of April 30. We continue to generate strong proportional free cash flow, which we relatively evenly distributed in the first and second half of the year. And with the settlement of all outstanding receivables at Maritza, we expect our first half proportional free cash flow to be well ahead of last year's. 
Regarding adjusted EPS, consistent with the first quarter, we also expect the second quarter to be lower than normal. In fact, we're forecasting that 70% to 75% of our 2016 adjusted EPS we recorded in the second half of 2016 versus about 60% in past years. There are a few reasons that our results were stronger in the second half than first half. 
First, we expect a lower tax rate the next 3 quarters. In any given year, there are certain items that influence quarterly rate, but tend to normalize on a full year basis. As I mentioned earlier, in the first quarter, we recognize a higher than usual tax expense, which we combined with relatively low first quarter earnings, had an outsized impact on our tax rate for the quarter. This tax expense was anticipated in our guidance. And accordingly, we continue to expect a 31% to 33% tax rate in 2016. 
Second, a higher concentration of scheduled maintenance in the first half of the year will position us for stronger performance in the second half. For example, San Nicolas, plants in Argentina, plant major maintenance the entire second quarter as part of its regular maintenance cycle that occurs about every 8 years. A few of our other plants have similar circumstances. 
Third, forward curves for FX and commodities reflect some improvement over the balance of the year, which will provide a benefit in the second half. Fourth, this year's $50 million in cost reductions is more heavily weighted towards the second half. And lastly, we expect to benefit from a couple of items that we are working on to partially offset lower demand in Brazil and our power prices in the U.S.  We are in a better position to discuss these later in the year. 
With that, I'll now turn it back over to Andres.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. To summarize our views on this call, we continue to generate strong proportional free cash flow, which will be evenly distributed between the first and second half of the year. Although we expect our first half adjusted EPS to be relatively w
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. To summarize our views on this call, we continue to generate strong proportional free cash flow, which will be evenly distributed between the first and second half of the year. Although we expect our first half adjusted EPS to be relatively weak, many of the negative drivers will reverse in the second half and therefore, we are reaffirming our guidance for all financial metrics. 
In terms of our strategic priorities, in the first few months of this year, we've made significant progress, including resolving the outstanding receivables issue in Bulgaria; receiving positive actions from the rating agencies resulting from our actions to derisk the portfolio and delever the parent; reaffirming our double-digit growth through 2018 in both cash flow and earnings, driven by our largely funded construction program and $150 million in cost savings and revenue enhancements; and achieving significant milestones on 3 new projects in our development pipeline to drive growth beyond 2018. 
I am optimistic about the future of AES. We are delivering strong and growing free cash flow, which we will continue to use to maximize risk-adjusted returns for our shareholders. The 6 gigawatts we currently have under construction is the largest driver of our expected growth of at least 10% in free cash flow through 2018. Beyond 2018, we are well-positioned to capture new opportunities due to our strong business platforms in attractive and growing markets and our leadership position in deploying new technologies. 
Now I'd like to open up the call for questions.

componenttext: Okay, great. And then my second question is about kind of, I guess, 2019 and beyond. I'm wondering, one, when we would potentially get more color on earnings that you're and cash flow that you're kind of terms of your overall growth rate and what that would mean specifically. And then I also wanted to understand within I guess that question the contracting structure of some of your success here on the LNG side. You have clearly, a recent Panama 1 particular power plant, where you have a 10-year contract. So I guess I understand that. But then how do you guys think about the risk and the structure of the actual importing of the LNG and the regas there and the selling of that to third parties?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, we tend to give our sort of longer-term forecasts in February. So that would be next year when we sort of move out an additional year. What we wanted to do was give you color that our growth will continue post-2018. In fact, that we have a goo
componenttext: Okay. Well, we tend to give our sort of longer-term forecasts in February. So that would be next year when we sort of move out an additional year. What we wanted to do was give you color that our growth will continue post-2018. In fact, that we have a good pipeline through 2020 that we recently added to. So that was really the point of this call. Now talking about the facility in Panama. Colon facility. So it has 2 parts. As you said, one's a 380-megawatt combined cycle of gas plant and 10-year PPA with a credit worthy offtaker in dollars. The second is a tank. And the tank, we are using about 1/4 of the capacity for this plant. This leaves about 3/4. So it's really a question of tolling. We're not going to be taking commodity risk on this. So this could be tolling fuel for other power plants. We did this in the Dominican Republic. We are using it. We built a pipeline to the -- our own actually BPP facility and converted from diesel to natural gas, and were also selling it in there to the transportation and industrial sectors. So what we would have in Panama is first to meet domestic demand. There are power plants nearby. There are other power plants that revealed that we think require natural gas. So that's first use. Transportation and industrial use will be second, following the model we had in the Dominican Republic. And third, which is very interesting is the ship bunkering. We would not be doing the bunkering. We will actually have somebody else do that, but they would use our storage and recap regas capacity. So the way to think about this is you'll basically bringing large efficient LNG tankers. You a load them in Panama and the Dominican Republic, and then you have various means of delivering gas to various types of customers or actually, LNG as well. So we did not plan to take any commodity risk per se on these transactions. We've been providing a service, regasification service, a bunkering service and a hub service. And between the 2, this gives us a very attractive position to be able to service people who want services in Panama and the Dominican Republic.

It's really '19 forward. And the storage tank will become fully operational in '19. So this is outside the window that we have given in the past. headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just to put a fine point. I think Sul has been running a loss, really running a loss really since middle of lesser. So last year, it was down about 20 million, 25 million in PTC. And this year, we're forecasting similar numbers. Angie, as we look at
componenttext: Yes, just to put a fine point. I think Sul has been running a loss, really running a loss really since middle of lesser. So last year, it was down about 20 million, 25 million in PTC. And this year, we're forecasting similar numbers. Angie, as we look at Sul, the earnings are -- we don't have Sul in our forecast for '17. And the inflection point for Sul will really be their rate, the next rate case, rate adjustment mechanism, which is in spring of '18, that's if we're to retain the business. In terms of Eletropaulo, the earnings were also very modest. We do have Eletropaulo, we do continue to have it in our business, but its contributions are between $0.00 and $0.02, depending upon your forecast for Brazil. So it's a fairly modest number.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016

componenttext: A question for you on the Batteries segment, which is one of the more unique aspects of the company. You mentioned that you're seeing growth through 2 paths. Of the 394 megawatts in operation construction-related development, is there a way you can breakout between what's AES versus sales AES? Or is that all AES owned project?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Those are all AES owned projects. So we don't have -- we're working very hard on these third-party sales. We have a lot of interesting projects we're working on, some with channel partners some in our own, and we hope to be. We'll be giving you new some t
componenttext: Those are all AES owned projects. So we don't have -- we're working very hard on these third-party sales. We have a lot of interesting projects we're working on, some with channel partners some in our own, and we hope to be. We'll be giving you new some time within the next 6 months. This is -- in many cases we are quite frankly, creating the market because were talking with regulators to make sure that the regulations are now compensations for a better-based energy storage. So yes, that's 100% art projects.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016

componenttext: Got you. And then I know because the market structures are still under development, each project is sort of a one-off situation. But in terms of modeling this growth area, can you give us any sort of rules of thumb about how to think about any modeling data points for example, like dollars. A W or return levels. Anything that we could you sit trying to get a little bit more specific on this.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a -- of the way we're looking at it. I mean, and you're correct. I mean, in some cases, we are putting up relatively small projects, sort of 10 megawatts, 20 megawatts, to open up a market. And a lot of the return we believe will come from thir
componenttext: Well, it's a -- of the way we're looking at it. I mean, and you're correct. I mean, in some cases, we are putting up relatively small projects, sort of 10 megawatts, 20 megawatts, to open up a market. And a lot of the return we believe will come from third-party sales. Now we also are seeing some markets that are more competitive and you have basically very rapid build-out of energy-based storage and so returns come down. We have others, but we are looking at sort of long-term contracts. So I think that the way we would look at the returns is that we would expect to earn on average the same as we earned in our other projects. We're not subsidizing this business. What will be new for us, quite frankly, is the third-party sales. Because there, we don't have to put in an equity. Essentially, we're using our intellectual property rights and our experience and the brand name of Advancion. So it's -- we haven't, quite frankly, incorporated the third-party sales because we really want to get a good feel from what they will be like. But with our channel partners, we are really casting a wide net. And we will see, I think, over the next 6, 12 months, much clear how big that business could get.

componenttext: Yes, I really -- at this stage, Lasanja, it's a little bit -- we're not ready to provide guidance, sort of 4, 5-year guidance out. Obviously, there's a lot of factors there that would influence us, what would forward exchange rate is going to be? What our commodity curves, energy prices? But what I think we feel very confident seeing is we're not going to sort of run out of growth projects in 2018. We already have significant projects that will come online 2019 and 2020. And we continue to work on ways to accelerate that rate of growth. And part of it is our partnerships and our sole done of assets to continue turn capital at the higher growth, higher return projects.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think in terms of cash flow and earnings, it's a fair statement. That's how we measure success. We're not going to measured in terms of megawatts and I think we're going to remain as a very disciplined company that we have been and will say over the las
componenttext: I think in terms of cash flow and earnings, it's a fair statement. That's how we measure success. We're not going to measured in terms of megawatts and I think we're going to remain as a very disciplined company that we have been and will say over the last 5 years. We're going to be very disciplined and make sure that again, not fall into a -- any sort of rapid growth sake, I mean, we really want to maximize. And I think one of the things we've shown is we're willing to Havel less megawatts less clients under operation but have a better risk profile and a better growth profile. That's really where we want to go.

componenttext: Sure. I think that it's true that Panama, which is owned by Duke in Tietê, we are once 1 company and then were split in 2. Having said that, when we're looking at our complete portfolio in terms of our risk profile, we have right now a lot of Brazil hydro risk. So this really isn't, we think, in our sweet spot at this point in time. And we also understand that they're going to sell the whole package together of all the other assets. It's a pretty big and their asset other assets that we're not interested in. So what I would say is that really, at this point, it's not something we are actively pursuing.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016

componenttext: Last question on Brazil. You have been long decision in recession, mild depression for the last couple of years. Do you think the Olympics will help bring it back out of that mode and back to more culpable economic profile? Or do you think it's Hendee to put the change to get there?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that Brazil is a much more diversified economy than perhaps that it gets credit for. I mean, if you look at the GDP in the state of San Paulo, it looks more like Belgian that it does to some of the Eastern states of Brazil. So to realize tha
componenttext: Well, I think that Brazil is a much more diversified economy than perhaps that it gets credit for. I mean, if you look at the GDP in the state of San Paulo, it looks more like Belgian that it does to some of the Eastern states of Brazil. So to realize that point. Now I think that Brazil got itself into this funk, some policy issues, not just commodity price drops. So the good thing is they can work their way out of it. Our view is that it'll probably take a couple of years at least of Brazil to get out of it. I don't think that the Olympics will have any effect whatsoever and I think the I think the key points for result is determined a political process, who is going to be the President within 6 months and what policies he will pursue. So having said that,, Brazil has a lot of strong points in its economy. So if they get their political act together and take that our structural changes, I'm sure it will be back within 5 years, I feel very confident that Brazil will be -- can be a strong economy again.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, but I have to ask one last question, which is if that's the case, then Brazil, it sounds like it's on a very fine line between great channels for divestiture versus great channels for expansion. AES has had [indiscernible] maybe still owns a la
componenttext: I'm sorry, but I have to ask one last question, which is if that's the case, then Brazil, it sounds like it's on a very fine line between great channels for divestiture versus great channels for expansion. AES has had [indiscernible] maybe still owns a large chunk of everything AES had the footprint in except for Sul. And there's been a lot of talk about privatizing being the BNDES interest. Is that something that you want to pursue more aggressively depending on the political situation? Or is it something that you would already like for a long time?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we can't speak for BNDES and what they decide to do with her assets. We did have the separation of our assets in Brazil to give us greater operating control in Tietê and greater capital structure and flexibility in general. So we've done that. And
componenttext: Well, we can't speak for BNDES and what they decide to do with her assets. We did have the separation of our assets in Brazil to give us greater operating control in Tietê and greater capital structure and flexibility in general. So we've done that. And I would say that if you look at what we've done in Brazil, we've certainly derisked ourselves significantly because we sold half of our holdings of Eletropaulo in 2006. We spun-off the telco from Eletropaulo, sold that for $1 billion. So we feel that we'll continue to manage Brazil sort of holistically and look at one of the fundamental exposures we have the there.

componenttext: Andres, just a follow-up that last question, you're probably most knowledgeable person about Brazil than I ever got a chance to ask a question to. In a quarter or 2 quarters ago, you talked about a turnaround in Brazil maybe 2018. And now, in response to the last question, I heard you say like more like 5 years. Has something happened in the last 3 months that makes you a little more pessimistic?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no. Let me clarify that. I do think that a turnaround in 2 years is still -- well, I would say, it's possible in may be sort of 50-50 chance. What I think within 5 years, I feel very optimistic at some point. I don't know if it's 3 years, 2 years, the
componenttext: No, no. Let me clarify that. I do think that a turnaround in 2 years is still -- well, I would say, it's possible in may be sort of 50-50 chance. What I think within 5 years, I feel very optimistic at some point. I don't know if it's 3 years, 2 years, they will come back. I think depending on the political resolution of the crisis they're facing now, wouldn't even be surprised that you have sort of a I wouldn't call it euphoria, but a pickup in sentiment in Brazil with the resolution. I mean, we've seen in that. You have certain political development. The actually appreciate in the market. So what I think is important to realize is that the crisis in Brazil has a lot to do with certain policies and not just a drop in commodity prices. So that makes the comeback more within their capabilities of doing.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the AES First Quarter 2016 Financial Review Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Ahmed Pasha, Vice President of Investor Rela
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the AES First Quarter 2016 Financial Review Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this event is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Ahmed Pasha, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dan. Good morning, and welcome to our first quarter financial review call. Our press release presentation and related financial information are available on our website at AES.com. Today, we will be making forward-looking statements during th
componenttext:
Thank you, Dan. Good morning, and welcome to our first quarter financial review call. Our press release presentation and related financial information are available on our website at AES.com. 
Today, we will be making forward-looking statements during the call. There are many factors that may cause future results to differ materially from these statements. Please refer to our SEC filings for a discussion of these factors.
Joining me this morning are: Andrés Gluski, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Tom O'Flynn, our Chief Financial Officer; and other senior members of our management team.
With that, I will now turn to the call over to Andrés. Andrés?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ahmed. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our first quarter financial review call. Today, I will discuss our first quarter results and provide updates on our progress on our strategic objectives, macro conditions in our markets a
componenttext:
Thank you, Ahmed. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our first quarter financial review call. Today, I will discuss our first quarter results and provide updates on our progress on our strategic objectives, macro conditions in our markets and our construction and development program. 
Since our last call in late February, we have achieved a number of key objectives for 2016. We received payment of all outstanding receivables in Bulgaria. We are on track to achieve our 3-year $150 million cost-reduction and revenue-enhancement goals. We saw improvements in our credit ratings and outlook from the rating agencies. Our $7.5 billion construction program is advancing on schedule and will be the major contributor to our cash and earnings growth over the next 3 years. 
We continue to leverage our existing business platforms by advancing projects with long-term contracts denominated in U.S. dollars. During the first quarter, we achieved significant milestones on 3 new projects, which will contribute to our growth after 2018. I will discuss these achievements in more detail in a moment. But first, I'd like to summarize our financial results on Slide 4. 
In the first quarter, we generated proportional free cash flow of $253 million, in line with last year. The recent collection of $350 million in Bulgaria will be reflected in our second quarter cash flow. Our first quarter adjusted EPS was $1 -- was $0.13, which is considerably lower than the $0.25 we earned last year. Our first quarter operating performance was impacted by adverse movements in FX, lower power prices in the U.S. and the expiration of the power purchase agreement at Tietê in Brazil. Our earnings performance was also driven by a tax rate of 50% for the first quarter, which is really a timing issue. We continue to expect a 31% to 33% tax rate for the full year. 
In terms of our outlook for the full year, we are reaffirming our guidance on all financial metrics. Nonetheless, we expect our first half adjusted EPS to be relatively weak due to the continuing impact from the factors I just mentioned and schedule major maintenance in the second quarter. Now I'll turn to our strategic accomplishments since our last call. 
As you can see on Slide 5, we have successfully resolved the outstanding receivables issue at Maritza in Bulgaria. Maritza's sole customer, the National Electricity Company, or NEK, had fallen significantly behind on its payments. In April, we received full payment of the outstanding receivables of $350 million. This is a direct result of the steps taken by the government of Bulgaria to strengthen the financial position of NEK and the long-term sustainability of the energy sector. By meeting all of its contractual obligations, Bulgaria is sending a very positive signal to all foreign investors. Currently, Maritza's providing clinically needed power to the Bulgarian electric grid, and we have been collecting in a timely manner since December 2015. 
Turning now to Slide 6 and our cost savings and revenue enhancement initiative. Our goal is to achieve a run rate of $150 million per year in bottom line improvement. We are on track to achieve our $50 million goal for 2016 and the additional $100 million through 2018. These bottom line benefits are largely driven by global procurement efforts, moving back-office functions to lower-cost service centers in Argentina and Bulgaria and continued improvements in the performance of our plans. 
Now turning to Slide 7. I'll discuss macro conditions in our markets. First, the impact from hydrology in Latin America should be negligible this year. While cumulative rainfall remains below average in Panama, it is generally improved in the rest of Latin America. Regarding Panama, spot prices have fallen significantly as a result of the barge base power plant we commissioned there last year, which reduced the effects of low rainfall on our contracted hydro plants. 
Second, economic conditions in our markets are generally in line with prior expectations, except for Brazil, which is experiencing a deepening recession. At our distribution businesses in Brazil, we are now seeing a second consecutive year of 5% decline in demand. While in the U.S., demand is essentially flat. In most of our other markets, we continue to see energy demand growth in the range of 4% to 10%. 
Moving on to Slide 8. We are focusing our investment efforts on platform expansion projects with long-term contracts and U.S. dollar-denominated revenues. We see a significant opportunity to take a leading role in the distribution and storage of LNG in Central America and the Caribbean. 
Turning to Slide 9. Let us review our major new projects. During the quarter, we started construction on the 335-megawatt Masinloc expansion to take advantage of robust growth in the Philippines and our existing infrastructure. The new unit, Masinloc 2, will be one of the most competitive thermal plants in the country, employing highly efficient and flexible supercritical technology. The $740 million project will be funded by a combination of nonrecourse financing, partner equity and cash generated at the Masinloc 1 facility. 
Moving on to slide 10. I am pleased to report that we have achieved a number of milestones on our Colon project in Panama. This project encompasses both a 380-megawatt combined cycle plant, or CCGT, and an adjacent LNG regasification terminal and storage facility. The CCGT is contracted under a 10-year U.S. dollar-denominated PPA. The LNG facility will have 180,000 cubic meter tank, which is sufficient to handle 80 terra BTU annually. Our CCGT will use about 1/4 of the tank's capacity, leaving substantial unused capacity to meet the needs of additional power plants or downstream customers. The Colon project seeks to replicate the success of our LNG facilities in the Dominican Republic, which provide gas to our adjacent power plant, another power plant via pipeline and to numerous downstream customers in the transportation and industrial sectors. The Colon project is strategically located near the entrance of the Panama Canal and will be able offer bunkering to the maritime industry as it starts to use natural gases of fuel. There are many commercial synergies between the LNG terminals in the Dominican Republic and Panama. And with both facilities in service, we will become the largest provider of LNG regasification and storage services in Central America and the Caribbean. 
All of the Colon project's permits are in place, and we have selected the EPC contractor. Project financing for approximately 60% of the project cost is well underway. AES' equity is expected to be around $200 million, which we will fund over the construction period. The project is expected to close in the second quarter of 2016 with completion of the power plant in 2018 and the LNG facility in 2019. 
As we can see on Slide 11, the repowering of Southland in California is another example of a large project that will contribute to our growth beyond 2018. As a reminder, we were awarded a 20-year PPA by Southern California Edison for 1,384 megawatts of capacity, which includes 100 megawatts of energy storage and 1,284 megawatts of combined cycle gas capacity. Since our last call, we have signed turbine supply agreements and EPC contracts to build the CCGT. We're making good progress on the remaining regulatory approvals and expect to break ground in 2017 with completion in 2020. We anticipate funding the $2 billion total project cost with a combination of nonrecourse debt and $500 million in equity from AES and a possible financial partner. 
Turning to Slide 12. We remain optimistic on the future battery base energy storage and our leadership position in this market. We currently have 116 megawatts of energy storage projects in operation across 4 countries and expect to install another 50 megawatts this year. Additionally, we have another 228 megawatts in advanced stage development, including the 100 megawatts under contract in California. By 2017, we expect to be operating in 7 countries, adding India, the Philippines and the Dominican Republic to the 4 countries where we already operate, the U.S., the U.K, the Netherlands and Chile. 
We see growth in our energy storage business through 2 paths. AES' own projects, such as the previously discussed 100 megawatts with the PPA with Southern California Edison and sales of our Advancion energy storage solution by AES and our channel partners. These sales will target utilities and other large energy storage customers. 
First, regarding long-term contracts. We see significant potential in many of our markets, including the U.S., the U.K., the Philippines and Mexico. We continue to work with local regulators to facilitate the development of market structures that enable new investments in battery-based energy storage. 
Second, over the past 8 years, we have learned a tremendous amount about how to integrate the various components to create a proprietary battery-based energy storage solution, which we have named Advancion. To promote Advancion sales in many more markets, we have executed channel partner agreements with Mitsubishi for sales in Asia and with Eaton for sales in Europe, the Middle East and Africa. We are in discussions with other potential partners to sell Advancion in additional markets. 
Although battery-based energy storage is still early on in its product cycle, we believe that Advancion presents an interesting opportunity for upside in our cash and earnings forecast. 
Turning now to our projects under construction on Slide 13. Our ongoing construction program is the most significant driver of our growth over the next few years. We expect to commission 6 gigawatts of new capacity from projects currently under construction through the first half of 2019. As a reminder, total capital expenditure for these projects is $7.5 billion. However, by using financial partners, AES' equity commitment is reduced to $1.3 billion. Of AES' equity commitment, all but $160 million has already been funded. 
As you can see on Slide 13, roughly 74% of our investments are in the Americas, and of this, a majority is in the U.S. and Chile. We expect an average return on equity from these projects of approximately 15%. About 3 gigawatts, representing half of the capacity currently under construction, are 90% complete and are on track to come online, on time and on budget this year. 
In 2017, we plan to commission an additional 670 megawatts of capacity in the U.S. and 112 megawatts in the Dominican Republic. We have completed about 70% of the work on these 2 projects, and we also expect them to come online, on time and on budget. 
The remaining 3 major projects now under construction, Masinloc 2, OPGC II and Alto Maipo, all projected to come online in late 2018 and early 2019. This construction program will drive visible and attractive growth in both free cash flow and earnings. 
As you can see on Slide 14, we expect at least 10% annual growth in proportional free cash flow through 2018, which will support our 10% annual growth in dividends, continued deleveraging of the parent and subsidiaries and investments in attractive platform expansions. 
Turning now to Slide 15. We also see robust growth in earnings through 2018. From 2016 to 2018, we expect an attractive growth rate of 12% to 16% in our adjusted EPS. Approximately 5% of this annual growth rate is driven by cost reductions and revenue enhancements. Another 8% to 10% of expected growth is driven by the 2.4 gigawatts of construction projects coming online in 2017 and 2018. 
Based on our strong market position and attractive high-growth markets, we're optimistic about our ability to drive growth beyond 2018. The 3 projects I just discussed, Masinloc 2, Colon and Southland, will come fully online after 2018. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Tom to discuss our first quarter results, capital allocation and full year guidance in more detail.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrés. Good morning, everyone. Today, I will review our first quarter results, including adjusted EPS, proportional free cash flow and adjusted pretax contribution, or PTC, by strategic business unit or SBU. And I'll cover our 2016 capital alloc
componenttext:
Thanks, Andrés. Good morning, everyone. Today, I will review our first quarter results, including adjusted EPS, proportional free cash flow and adjusted pretax contribution, or PTC, by strategic business unit or SBU. And I'll cover our 2016 capital allocation as well as our 2016 guidance. 
Turning to Slide 17. First quarter adjusted EPS of $0.13 was $0.12 lower than 2015. Much of this decline was driven by factors incorporated into our full year guidance with certain exceptions, primarily the decline in power markets in the U.S. as well as lower demand in Brazil. Specifically, our results reflect the $0.04 impact from a significantly higher quarterly tax rate of 50% in 2016 versus 33% in '15. This was mostly driven by the timing of certain tax expenses, the largest of which was the enactment of income tax reforms in Chile. We do expect the rate to recover during the year to a full year tax rate of 31% to 33%. 
Next, the $0.04 impact from the valuation of foreign currencies as expected, primarily in Latin America and Europe. And also $0.05 lower contributions from our SBUs, mainly due to anticipated drivers such as the expiration of Tietê's PPA with Eletropaulo. 
In addition to the drivers included in our expectations, we also saw some softness in power markets and mild weather in the U.S. That being said, we've seen some recovery in prices in the last month, which will contribute to our stronger second half of the year and helps give us comfort in our full year outlook. 
Now to Slide 18. Our overall results were primarily driven by lower margins in our Brazil, Europe and U.S. SBUs due to the factors I just mentioned. We generated $253 million in proportional free cash flow, a modest decrease of $12 million from last year, reflecting lower margins, mostly offset by higher collections at our Brazil utilities and lower working capital requirements in Vietnam. We also warrant $172 million in adjusted PTC during the quarter, a decrease of $80 million. 
Now I'll cover our SBUs in more detail over the next 6 slides beginning on Slide 19. In the U.S., our results reflect lower margins at DPL due to lower wholesale prices and lower contributions from regulated customers, lower contributions from IPL due to mild weather and a partial sell down and the sale of Armenia Mountain wind project. Proportional free cash flow also reflects unfavorable working capital changes at IPL. 
In Andes, our results reflect the 40% devaluation of the Argentine peso, 24% deval of the Columbia peso and lower volumes at Chivor in Colombia. Proportional free cash flow was also impacted by higher tax payments in Chile. PTC also reflects lower equity and earnings at Guacolda in Chile. 
In Brazil, our results reflect lower margins to the expiration of Tietê's PPA with Eletropaulo in 2015, lower demand at Sul and Eletropaulo and the 26% evaluation of the Brazilian real. Proportional free cash flow also reflects higher collections at Sul and Eletropaulo as well as the favorable timing of energy purchases at Tietê. 
Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean, our results reflect modestly lower margins. Proportional free cash flow largely reflects higher-than-normal collections in the Dominican Republic in 2015. 
In Europe, our results reflect lower margins due to the 48% devaluation of the Kazakhstan tenge and lower dark spreads at Kilroot in the U.K. Proportional free cash flow also effects the timing of payments to the fuel supplier Maritza in Bulgaria and the unfavorable timing of working capital and tax payments in the U.K. 
Finally, in Asia, our results benefited from higher margins and lower buildup of working capital as a result of the start of operations at Mong Duong in Vietnam in April of 2015. 
Turning to Slide 25. I'll now provide an update on our regulatory filing at DPL in Ohio. As you may recall, in February, DPL filed its Electric Security Plan. Since that time, there have been challenges to regulation in Ohio. We saw the potential for similar arguments to impact the structure of other utilities' proposals pending before the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio. Consequently, when we filed our plan, we included an alternative proposal that provided an option for the PUCO to approve a non-bypassable charge structured in the same way as the one approved in our existing ESP. We believe that this alternative falls under the PUCO's authority and also achieve the policy goals set up by the commission. We continue to believe this alternative provides a viable path forward for DPL and Ohio, and the commission is seeking for a reasonable resolution for the matter before the end of this year. 
Turning now to our 2016 parent capital allocation on Slide 26. Sources on the left-hand slide continue to reflect $1.1 billion of total available discretionary cash, which includes $575 million in parent free cash flow and announced asset sales. We remain confident in our 2016 parent free cash flow range of $525 million to $625 million, which are the foundation of our discretionary cash available for dividend growth and value creation. 
Turning to the uses on the right-hand side of the slide, consistent with our capital allocation plan that we've showed during our last call, with 10% growth in our dividend and share repurchases year-to-date, we're returning at least 1/3 of this cash to shareholders. Going forward, we see our dividend as the primary means to distribute cash to shareholders. 
Stock repurchases should be less material, absent proceeds from additional asset sales and partnerships. 
Regarding debt reduction, we're making good progress on our $200 million target for the year in our longer-term goal of parent credit improvement. In fact, year-to-date, we've prepaid $125 million of parent debt. Taking advantage of weak market conditions early in the quarter, we were able to buy this debt at a 7% discount. 
We're also seeing positive momentum on the ratings front. In March, Moody's changed our parent credit outlook from stable to positive. And in April, S&P upgraded our rating from BB- to BB. These actions reflect our continued efforts to derisk our portfolio and improve our credit metrics. 
We think the continuing to strengthen our credit will help us get better recognition and valuation for our growing cash flow and dividend. This positive credit trend, along with an overall market improvement, has allowed us to continue to be opportunistic regarding refinancing and extending maturities. To that end, last week, we extended an $800 million parent revolver maturity from 2018 to 2021. Also last week, on the nonrecourse side, our business in the Dominican Republic was able to replace a short-term financing with a new $370 million, 10-year bond at more favorable terms. 
We've also earmarked $330 million for investments in our subsidiaries, but 1/3 of which is through our Colon project in Panama and at Southland in California coming online after 2018. 
Finally, after considering these investments in our subs, our current dividend and debt prepayment were left with roughly $150 million of discretionary cash, which we'll invest consistent with our capital allocation framework. As the year's past, much of this cash is weighted towards the latter part of the year. 
Now to slide 27. We are reaffirming our guidance in 2017, '18 expectations for all metrics based on foreign currency and commodity forward curves as of April 30. We continue to generate strong proportional free cash flow, which we relatively evenly distributed in the first and second half of the year. And with the settlement of all outstanding receivables at Maritza, we expect our first half proportional free cash flow to be well ahead of last year's. 
Regarding adjusted EPS, consistent with the first quarter, we also expect the second quarter to be lower than normal. In fact, we're forecasting that 70% to 75% of our 2016 adjusted EPS we recorded in the second half of 2016 versus about 60% in past years. 
There are a few reasons that our results to be stronger in the second half than first half. First, we expect a lower tax rate in the next 3 quarters. In any given year, there are certain items that influence the quarterly rate, but tend to normalize on a full year basis. As I mentioned earlier, in the first quarter, we recognize a higher-than-usual tax expense, which we combine with relatively low first quarter earnings, had an outsized impact on our tax rate for the quarter. This tax expense was anticipated in our guidance. And accordingly, we continue to expect a 31% to 33% tax rate in 2016. 
Second, the higher concentration of scheduled maintenance in the first half of the year will position us for stronger performance in the second half. For example, San Nicolas plant in Argentina, [indiscernible] planned major maintenance of the entire second quarter as part of its regular maintenance cycle that occurs about every 8 years. A few of our other plants have similar circumstances. 
Third, forward curves for FX and commodities reflect some improvement over the balance of the year, which will provide a benefit in the second half. Fourth, this year's $50 million in cost reductions is more heavily weighted towards the second half. And lastly, we expect to benefit from a couple of items that we're working on to partially offset lower demand in Brazil and lower power prices in the U.S.  We'll be in a better position to discuss these later in the year. 
With that, I'll now turn it back over to Andrés.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. To summarize our views on this call, we continue to generate strong proportional free cash flow, which will be evenly distributed between the first and second half of the year. Although we expect our first half adjusted EPS to be relatively w
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. To summarize our views on this call, we continue to generate strong proportional free cash flow, which will be evenly distributed between the first and second half of the year. Although we expect our first half adjusted EPS to be relatively weak, many of the negative drivers will reverse in the second half, and therefore, we are reaffirming our guidance for all financial metrics. 
In terms of our strategic priorities, in the first few months of this year, we've made significant progress, including resolving the outstanding receivables issue in Bulgaria; receiving positive actions from the rating agencies resulting from our actions to derisk the portfolio and delever the parent; reaffirming our double-digit growth through 2018 in both cash flow and earnings, driven by our largely funded construction program and $150 million in cost savings and revenue enhancements; and achieving significant milestones on 3 new projects in our development pipeline to drive growth beyond 2018. 
I am optimistic about the future of AES. We are delivering strong and growing free cash flow, which we will continue to use to maximize risk-adjusted returns for our shareholders. The 6 gigawatts we currently have under construction is the largest driver of our expected growth of at least 10% in free cash flow through 2018. Beyond 2018, we are well positioned to capture new opportunities due to our strong business platforms in attractive and growing markets and our leadership position in deploying new technologies. 
Now I'd like to open up the call for questions.

componenttext: Yes, I would say that again, we believe that our proposal voided some of the issues raised by the PPAs. We continue to feel that that's the correct path to go, and we feel optimistic. We feel it's in everybody's interest. So at this point, what we would like to do is we continue to go with that path. And you are correct that there's a certain amount of volatility due to the on-contract nature of the generation assets at DP&L, which is separate from that. But we have to -- especially if we get the non-liability rider, we have to think of it as an integrated business at that point.

componenttext: Well, we've announced in the past that we'd be selling likely, on average, $200 million to $300 million in equity proceeds to us of sell-downs and getting out of certain businesses, and we continue. I think, we've, quite frankly, outperformed the numbers that we've given in the past. Now we don't comment on them. But what we would be doing again is fine-tuning our portfolio to have really sort of an optimal mix of risks and position. So yes, we'll continue to do that. And in terms of what we do with the proceeds, we'll continue to allocate them as we have in terms of a mix, whether be new investments and debt pay-downs, and we'll see what the circumstances are. As Tom said, I think there's more of a -- we'll have more of an emphasis on the growth of dividends than we have had in the past.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then my second question is about kind of, I guess, 2019 and beyond. I'm wondering, one, when we would potentially get more color on earnings that you're -- in the cash flow that you're kind of terms of your overall growth rate and what th
componenttext: Okay, great. And then my second question is about kind of, I guess, 2019 and beyond. I'm wondering, one, when we would potentially get more color on earnings that you're -- in the cash flow that you're kind of terms of your overall growth rate and what that would mean specifically. And then I also wanted to understand within, I guess, that question the contracting structure of some of your success here on the LNG side. You have clearly, a list of Panama, 1 particular power plant where you have a 10-year contract. So I guess I understand that. But then how do you guys think about the risk and the structure of the actual importing of the LNG and the re-gas there and the selling of that to third parties?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, we tend to give our sort of longer-term forecast in February. So that would be next year when we sort of move out an additional year. What we wanted to do was give you color that our growth will continue post-2018. In fact, that we have a good
componenttext: Okay. Well, we tend to give our sort of longer-term forecast in February. So that would be next year when we sort of move out an additional year. What we wanted to do was give you color that our growth will continue post-2018. In fact, that we have a good pipeline through 2020 that we recently added to. So that was really the point of this call. Now talking about the facility in Panama, colon facility, so it has 2 parts. As you said, one's a 380-megawatt combined cycle gas plant on a 10-year PPA with a credit worthy off-taker in dollars. The second is a tank. And the tank, we are using about 1/4 of the capacity for this plant. This leaves about 3/4. So it's really a question of tolling. We're not going to be taking commodity risk on this. So this could be tolling fuel for other power plants. We did this in the Dominican Republic. We're using it. We built a pipeline to the -- our own actually DPP facility and converted from diesel to natural gas, and we're also selling it there to the transportation and industrial sectors. So what we would have in Panama is, first, to meet domestic demand. There are power plants nearby. There are other power plants that will be built that we think require natural gas. So that's first use. Transportation and industrial use will be second, following the model we had in the Dominican Republic. And third, which is very interesting is the ship bunkering. We would not be doing the bunkering. We will actually have somebody else to do that, but they would use our storage and regas capacity. So the way to think about this is you'll basically bringing large efficient LNG tankers. You unload them in Panama and the Dominican Republic, and then you have various means of delivering gas to various types of customers or actually, LNG as well. So we do not plan to take any commodity risk per se on these transactions. We've been providing a service, regasification service, a bunkering service and a hub service. And between the two, this gives us a very attractive position to be able to service people who want services in Panama and the Dominican Republic.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Angie Storozynski of Macquarie.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So my first question is -- so this Panama CCGT, you mentioned that's going to start operations in '18. Did you have it previously in your earnings expectations for '18 and if that's what's actually causing the guidance to move towards the high end, the pe
componenttext: So my first question is -- so this Panama CCGT, you mentioned that's going to start operations in '18. Did you have it previously in your earnings expectations for '18 and if that's what's actually causing the guidance to move towards the high end, the percentage wise? That's one. And two, could you comment if you have any earnings contributions for Sul and Eletropaulo in your guidance in '17 and '18?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I'll take the first. No, this was not in our guidance previously. Now realize that the power plant will come online late in '18. So it really won't have any effect on '18. It's really '19 forward. And the storage tank will become fully operationa
componenttext: Okay. So I'll take the first. No, this was not in our guidance previously. Now realize that the power plant will come online late in '18. So it really won't have any effect on '18. It's really '19 forward. And the storage tank will become fully operational in '19. So this is outside the window that we have given in the past. Regarding, I think, Tom can talk about the contributions of Sul and EP.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just to put a fine point. I think Sul has been running a loss. It's been running a loss really since middle of last year. So last year, it was down about $20 million, $25 million in PTC. And this year, we're forecasting similar numbers. Angie, as we
componenttext: Yes, just to put a fine point. I think Sul has been running a loss. It's been running a loss really since middle of last year. So last year, it was down about $20 million, $25 million in PTC. And this year, we're forecasting similar numbers. Angie, as we look at Sul, the earnings are -- we don't have Sul in our forecast for '17. And the inflection point for Sul will really be their rate, the next rate case, rate adjustment mechanism, which is in spring of '18, where we do -- that's if we were to retain the business. In terms of Eletropaulo, the earnings were also very modest. We do have Eletropaulo, we do continue to have it in our business, but the -- its contributions are between $0.00 and $0.02, depending upon your forecast for Brazil. So it's fairly modest number.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016

componenttext: Yes. Again, our thoughts are -- quite frankly, we see that our filing -- we think it has been the correct path to take, and we think it's within the PUCO per view to grant this. componenttext: Okay. And then just on the longer-term drivers, you've given great visibility on the growth new drivers and particularly new projects. componenttext: I would say that the only one we have is really Southland, that's where we're repowering. That's more than sort of 2020 time frame that we have the roll-offs. And I'd say that's basically -- I mean, in DPL, we have the -- our application for 2017, where I fairly would eliminate any such cliff at DPL. So we have nothing else major out there.

componenttext: Just to -- and this is the Southland. So that's the only we have where the PPA expires, so we're going to repower the plant.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Brian Chin of Bank of America.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question for you on the batteries segment, which is one of the more unique aspects of the company. You mentioned that you're seeing growth through 2 paths. Of the 394 megawatts in operation construction-related development, is there a way that you can b
componenttext: A question for you on the batteries segment, which is one of the more unique aspects of the company. You mentioned that you're seeing growth through 2 paths. Of the 394 megawatts in operation construction-related development, is there a way that you can breakout between what AES owned versus sales by AES? Or is that all AES-owned project you've listed?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Those are all AES-owned projects. So we don't have -- we're working very hard on these third-party sales. We have a lot of interesting projects we're working on, some with channel partners some in our own, and we hope to be. We'll be giving you news somet
componenttext: Those are all AES-owned projects. So we don't have -- we're working very hard on these third-party sales. We have a lot of interesting projects we're working on, some with channel partners some in our own, and we hope to be. We'll be giving you news sometime within the next 6 months. This is -- in many cases, we're, quite frankly, creating the market because we're talking with regulators to make sure that the regulations allow compensation for battery-based energy storage. So yes, that's 100% art projects.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And then I know because the market structures are still under development, each project is sort of a one-off situation. But in terms of modeling this growth area, can you give us any sort of rules of thumb about how to think about any modeling da
componenttext: Got you. And then I know because the market structures are still under development, each project is sort of a one-off situation. But in terms of modeling this growth area, can you give us any sort of rules of thumb about how to think about any modeling data points, for example, like dollars per KW or return levels? Just anything that we can use to try and get a little bit more specific on this.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's -- the way we're looking at it. I mean -- and you're correct. I mean, in some cases, we are putting up relatively small projects, sort of 10 megawatts, 20 megawatts, to open up a market. And a lot of the return, we believe, will come from third
componenttext: Well, it's -- the way we're looking at it. I mean -- and you're correct. I mean, in some cases, we are putting up relatively small projects, sort of 10 megawatts, 20 megawatts, to open up a market. And a lot of the return, we believe, will come from third-party sales. Now we also are seeing some markets that are more competitive, and you have basically very rapid build-out of energy-based storage and so returns come down. We have others, but we're looking at sort of long-term contracts. So I think that the way we would look at the returns is that we would expect to earn, on average, the same as we earned in other -- our other projects. We're not subsidizing this business. What will be new for us, quite frankly, is the third-party sales because there, we don't have to put in any equity. Essentially, we're using our intellectual property rights and our experience and the brand name of Advancion. So it's -- we haven't, quite frankly, incorporated the third-party sales because we really want to get a good feel from what they will be like. But with our channel partners, we are really casting a wide net. And we will see, I think, over the next 6, 12 months, much clearer how big that business could get.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
